Award.AbstractNarration:
The Riemann Hypothesis is a celebrated unsolved problem in pure mathematics that dates back to 1859. Its motivation is to find a precise count for the number of prime numbers up to a large quantity. In modern times the Riemann Hypothesis is recognized as one of a host of similar problems about the underlying structure of nearly every counting problem that arises in number theory. In order to stimulate progress on this problem a three-and-a-half day conference will be held at the University of Bristol June 4 - 7, 2018 for up to 140 participants. There will be about 15 lectures during the meeting and there will be time scheduled for discussion of promising avenues. It is important that U.S. based researchers attend this meeting; especially recent PhD recipients and researchers from under-represented groups are encouraged to apply to attend. This award will help support that particular effort.
The website for the conference is

https://heilbronn.ac.uk/2017/08/08/perspectives-on-the-riemann-hypothesis/

It is believed that the analogue of the Riemann Hypothesis should hold for every L-function in the Selberg Class, or equivalently for every cuspidal automorphic L-function of a certain type. There are literally dozens of approaches that have been tried. An expected outcome of this meeting is that various approaches with similarities will be grouped together in order to better assess their viability. In this way the focus will be narrowed to a few of the more promising avenues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Riemann Hypothesis is a central problem in mathematics. On its surface it is about the distribution of prime numbers but now we know that it is germane to a large swath of mathematics and physics. It was originally stated in 1859 and has stimulated hundreds of papers with dozens of approaches. 

In 1996 the American Institute of Mathematics (AIM) held its first meeting on the Riemann Hypothesis (RH). That meeting waqs designed to stimulate research on the problem in the hopes of finding a solution. That conference was followed on by a conference in 1998 and one in 2002. Much interesting work ensued but still today we find ourselves apparently very far from a solution. That is why AIM decided to propose another conference 20 plus years after the first one. This grant partially supported 21 attendees, especially women, junior, and academics from non-research I colleges and universities to attend the June, 2018 conference ``Perspectives on the Riemann Hypothesis'' at the University of Bristol. 

More than 150 people in total attended this 4-day conference which was supported by the NSF, AIM, Unievrsity of Bristol, the Heilbronn Institute and the Clay Mathematics Institute. Altogether there were 16 talks and a discussion of open problems surrounding the Riemann Hypothesis. Slides from the talks and videos of the talks and problem session are available at https://aimath.org/rh2018/

Some of the highlights included an update by Alain Connes on his approach to RH; a report by Enrico Bombieri and Paul Garrett on their new approach;  a talk by Keith Ball outlining his new approach based on rational functions; and a talk by Terry Tao on his new work with Brad Rodgers on something called von Neumann's constant.  The video and written account of the problem session will be useful for yars to come. 

There were a number of junior participants at the conference which bodes well for the future of the subject. And the international nature of the conference was responsible for interactions and potential collaborations among researchers all ove rthe world.
